unnormalised: Okay, here's the blog post text, generated according to the parameters you provided:
normalised: The headline screamed from my phone screen: "India to Land on Moon by two thousand and thirty!" It was eleven forty seven P-M on a Tuesday, and I was just settling down with chai after a long day of data entry. Seriously? Another space mission? I clicked the link.

unnormalised: The headline screamed from my phone screen: “India to Land on Moon by 2030!” It was 11:47 PM on a Tuesday, and I was just settling down with chai after a long day of data entry. Seriously? Another space mission? I clicked the link.
normalised: The article started by saying "I-S-R-O confirmed plans to launch Chandrayaan four by two thousand and thirty". I remember reading about Chandrayaan three's successful landing on twenty third august two thousand and twenty three. This one promised something even more ambitious: a sample return mission. Apparently, they were aiming for a launch window between first january two thousand and thirty and thirty first december two thousand and thirty. Ambitious, to say the least.

unnormalised: The article started by saying “ISRO confirmed plans to launch Chandrayaan-4 by 2030”. I remember reading about Chandrayaan-3's successful landing on 23/08/2023. This one promised something even more ambitious: a sample return mission. Apparently, they were aiming for a launch window between 01/01/2030 and 31/12/2030. Ambitious, to say the least.
normalised: My mind flashed back to childhood. We’d sit on the terrace during summer vacations, staring at the moon. Dadi used to tell stories about astronauts travelling there. Now, it seemed like these stories were becoming reality, and on such a quick timeline! Who knew that less than one hundred years after independence on fifteenth august nineteen forty seven, we'd be planning such advanced missions?

unnormalised: My mind flashed back to childhood. We’d sit on the terrace during summer vacations, staring at the moon. Dadi used to tell stories about astronauts travelling there. Now, it seemed like these stories were becoming reality, and on such a quick timeline! Who knew that less than 100 years after independence on 15/08/1947, we'd be planning such advanced missions?
normalised: The blog post continued, "Detailed plans will be revealed on fifteenth september two thousand and twenty four at ten zero zero A-M during a press conference." That was just a few weeks away! I immediately added it to my Google Calendar. It also mentioned something about collaboration with N-A-S-A, targeting a launch around seven thirty A-M I-S-T to coincide with optimal alignment.

unnormalised: The blog post continued, “Detailed plans will be revealed on 15/09/2024 at 10:00 AM during a press conference.” That was just a few weeks away! I immediately added it to my Google Calendar. It also mentioned something about collaboration with NASA, targeting a launch around 07:30 AM IST to coincide with optimal alignment.
normalised: It was intriguing. The journalist, a M-S. Aishwarya Krishnan, speculated about the potential scientific breakthroughs. She wrote, "Experts believe samples from the moon could unlock secrets dating back to the formation of our solar system, possibly even before first january four billion five hundred million B-C." It's amazing to think that information might be in our grasp soon.

unnormalised: It was intriguing. The journalist, a Ms. Aishwarya Krishnan, speculated about the potential scientific breakthroughs. She wrote, “Experts believe samples from the moon could unlock secrets dating back to the formation of our solar system, possibly even before 01/01/4500000000 BC.” It's amazing to think that information might be in our grasp soon.
normalised: Of course, the comments section was already buzzing. One user wrote, "two thousand and thirty is too far! Why not prepone to two thousand and twenty eight?". Another post from at Space Fanboy India stated "Will there be livestream on YouTube like three months ago? I missed first fifteen minutes of Chandrayaan three and don’t wanna miss out again!". Everyone had an opinion, and that's what was great about the Indian internet.

unnormalised: Of course, the comments section was already buzzing. One user wrote, "2030 is too far! Why not prepone to 2028?". Another post from @SpaceFanboyIndia stated "Will there be livestream on YouTube like 3 months ago? I missed first 15 mins of Chandrayaan-3 and don’t wanna miss out again!". Everyone had an opinion, and that's what was great about the Indian internet.
normalised: I started thinking about what this all meant. A new chapter in Indian space exploration? A boost to our scientific reputation on the world stage? Or just another news cycle that would fade away after a few weeks. Either way, it was an interesting piece of news to receive late on twentieth june two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: I started thinking about what this all meant. A new chapter in Indian space exploration? A boost to our scientific reputation on the world stage? Or just another news cycle that would fade away after a few weeks. Either way, it was an interesting piece of news to receive late on 20/06/2024.
normalised: I shut down my computer, the image of the moon still lingering in my mind. Maybe one day, I thought, my grandkids will look up at the sky and say, "Dadi, did you see the astronauts land on the moon back in two thousand and thirty?” Now, back to my chai.
